message.content:
cs.CL, cs.SI, cs.SOC, cs.IR, cs.LG 

This paper is likely to belong to the sub-category of Computational Linguistics (cs.CL) as it deals with designing linguistic patterns to extract users' preferences on Twitter. It may also belong to the sub-category of Social and Information Networks (cs.SI) as it involves analyzing user behavior on a social network. Additionally, it could be categorized under the sub-category of Social Computing (cs.SOC) as it deals with modeling user preferences in online debates. Information Retrieval (cs.IR) is another possible sub-category as the paper involves extracting statements from a collection of tweets. Lastly, the paper's use of matrix factorization to model user preferences could also place it under the sub-category of Machine Learning (cs.LG).
